ygData.subject: Re: [neat] Re: AHNI now supports computing clusters

Hi Ken,

Yes, I've tested and verified all of these variants and extensions=
 apart
from ES-HyperNEAT. I've just added a note to the readme about this l=
ast one:

NOTE: A lot of time was spent checking every aspect of the ES-Hyp=
erNEAT
implementation however it was not possible to reproduce the experime=
nts in
Risi S. and Stanley K.O. (2012) An Enhanced Hypercube-Based Encoding=
 for
Evolving the Placement, Density and Connectivity of Neurons, Artificia=
l
Life, MIT Press, thus the implementation should be assumed to be be not
w=
orking. Feel free to try it out and let me know how you go! :)

Cheers,
Oli=
ver


T: 0421 972 953 | E: oliver.coleman@... | W: http://ojcoleman.c=
om


On 16 March 2015 at 16:03, kstanley@... [neat] <
neat@yahoog=
roups.com> wrote:

>
>
> Hi Oliver, thanks for your work on AHNI, cluster c=
ompatibility is very
> useful.  As with other areas of machine learning, ne=
uroevolution is likely
> to benefit from massive and increasing computation=
al power, so it's good if
> our software can take advantage of it.
>
> By t=
he way, I see notes in your github for support of all kinds of
> variants a=
s well, such as ES-HyperNEAT, LEO, NSGA-II, and novelty search.
> Are all t=
hose really working well and validated?  If so I'd add mention of
> them to=
 my software links collection (
> http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software=
).  I'm also planning to
> overhaul that list because it's become so large =
and disorganized that new
> people coming in can't figure out which package=
 they should really be
> choosing.  My plan is to make it a lot more helpfu=
l in pointing people to
> what they need.  But anyway AHNI deserves to be f=
eatured prominently.
>
> Best,
>
> ken
>  
>

--001a113ec9f212049e0511874491

    <div>
      
      
      <p>Hi Oliver, thanks for your work on AH=
NI, cluster compatibility is very useful.=C2=A0 As with other areas of mach=
ine learning, neuroevolution is likely to benefit from massive and increasi=
ng computational power, so it's good if our software can take advantage=
 of it.=C2=A0 <br><br>By the way, I see notes in your github for support of=
 all kinds of variants as well, such as ES-HyperNEAT, LEO, NSGA-II, and nov=
elty search.=C2=A0 Are all those really working well and validated?=C2=A0 I=
f so I'd add mention of them to my software links collection (<a href=
=3D"http://www.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software" target=3D"_blank">http://www=
.cs.ucf.edu/~kstanley/#software</a>).=C2=A0 I'm also planning to overha=
ul that list because it's become so large and disorganized that new peo=
ple coming in can't figure out which package they should really be choo=
sing.=C2=A0 My plan is to make it a lot more helpful in pointing people to =
what they need.=C2=A0 But anyway AHNI deserves to be featured prominently.<=
br><br>Best,<br><br>ken=C2=A0</p>

    </div>
